University of Genova, DICCA, Department of Civil Chemical and Environmental Engineering Via all’Opera Pia 15 Genova 16145 Italy 1 Equal contribution Ru/Al2O3 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared and investigated in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. 0.5 wt% Ru/Al2O3, 2 wt% Ni/Al2O3, and 13.6 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by using a modified incipient wetness impregnation with a main focus on the effect of solvent selection and catalyst pretreatment conditions on the catalyst reduction, activity, selectivity, activation energy, and morphology. In-depth characterizations, including FT-IR, FE-SEM, and XRD, were performed on the catalysts, and an operando study was carried out on the best-performing Ru-catalysts in COx transient experiments at 523 K. The investigation revealed that employing ethanol as the solvent for preparation results in a catalyst with improved properties and activity. Furthermore, coupling solvent selection with various pretreatment conditions demonstrated that specific pretreatments can significantly affect the catalyst properties, activity, and morphology. Operando IR confirmed the mechanism and the effect of CO reported in the literature, even if a different distribution of carbonyl species was detected. Graphical Abstract Keywords Hydrogenation CO2 methanation Catalyst design Ruthenium-alumina Solvent Pretreatment Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the recent years, hydrogenation of captured CO2 with renewable hydrogen has received much attention as a possible way for carbon dioxide valorization and reuse, especially in the frame of the so-called “Power to Gas” (PtG) technologies, which offer promising solutions for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and building up a green energy cycle [1,2] recognizing H2 availability and price as the bottlenecks for the widespread adoption of such technology. The main reaction, known as Sabatier’s reaction, is (1) CO2(g) + 4H2(g) ⇌ CH4(g) + 2H2O(g) ΔH° 298 = -165 kJ/mol that can be carried out in thermochemical [3,4] plasma [5] and biological ways [6], being the resulting methane a type of Synthetic or Substitute Natural Gas (SNG) [7–9], similar to that produced by converting syngases coming from coal gasification. If electrolytic hydrogen is used for CO2 hydrogenation, e-methane is produced, representing a sustainable e-fuel that can be transported in existing natural gas networks after being upgraded to match the natural gas grid requirements set in each EU country in terms of Wobbe index and composition [10]. The same process can also produce hydrogen-methane mixtures, called “hydromethane”, that is a promising and attractive fuel option for vehicles [11]. However, it should be considered that CO2 conversion to methane is competitive with the production of CO through the so-called “Reverse Water Gas Shift” reaction, RWGS [12], (2) CO2(g) + H2(g) ⇌ CO(g) + H2O(g) ΔH° 298 = +41.16 kJ/mol and with the possible reduction of COx to elemental carbon according to reactions (3) and (4) (3) CO2(g) + 2H2(g) ⇌ C(s) + 2H2O(g) ΔH° 298 = -90.1 kJ/mol (4) CO(g) + H2(g) ⇌ C(s) + H2O(g) ΔH° 298 = -131.3 kJ/mol where the Boudouard equilibrium reaction might be accounted (5). (5) 2CO(g) ⇌ C(s) + CO2(g) ΔH° 298 = -172.4 kJ/mol Therefore, catalyst choice plays a crucial role by enhancing the CO2 reaction rate and ensuring high selectivity toward methane production with a reduced carbon deposition and guaranteeing, at the same time, a remarkable thermal stability for the forecasted temperature increase as a function of the chosen reactor and process layouts [13]. Among various catalysts explored for CO2 methanation, those based on Ru [14–17] and Ni [1,2,18–20] have shown significant potential also at the commercial scale level, such as METH 134 and METH 135 commercialized by Clariant, consisting of alumina-supported NiO with 25 and 43 wt% loading, shaped as spheres and operated in a standard syngas plant above 473 K [21]. For low-temperature applications (T < 443 K), primarily related to the COx methanation in hydrogen or ammonia synthesis gas, Clariant provides METH 150, which consists of ruthenium (0.3 wt%) on an alumina support in tablet form. In recent applications, SNG 100 DCARB has also been reported; however, no specifications are provided for its composition and active phase types. Topsøe reported in TREMP™ RNG process [22] that different pre-reduced catalysts, such as MCR-2 and MCR-8, are used for medium and high-temperature methanation in the form of cylinders (for MCR-8) or 7-hole cylinders (for both MCR-2 and MCR-8). In contrast, the PK-7R catalyst is designed explicitly for low-temperature applications and is sold, pre-reduced, in the form of ring-shaped catalysts. In previous reports, MCR-2X was also reported as a Ni-based catalyst over a stabilized support [23], while PK-7R is reported to have a Ni loading higher than 23 wt% [23]. Johnson Matthey produced DAVY™ with CRG catalyst series [24] for coal-derived syngas to methane, and the KATALCO 11 series with a nickel loading of 35 wt% [25]. Ni-based catalysts are prone to sintering and coke deactivation, but guarantee a wide operation range up to 1000 K [26–30], whereas 0.5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 catalysts exhibit a remarkable low-temperature activity [17,31,32] (above 97 %, accounting for temperature inhomogeneities) in a 2 kW plant with a space velocity of 0.14 s−1 [33], even though catalyst cost can increase by a factor 2.5 when compared with Ni-ones, according to data reported from Zuttel’s group [34]. In addition, the higher catalytic activity of Ru-based catalysts at lower temperatures opens the possibility of achieving a wider CO2 conversion range by considering the involved thermodynamic equilibrium. At the laboratory scale, Garbarino and coworkers [35–38] and Gonzales Velasco and coworkers agreed on a suitable Ni loading for CO2 hydrogenation of 12 wt% and of 4 wt% in the Ru case [39], when supported over commercial alumina and starting from nickel nitrate and ruthenium nitrosyl nitrate as precursors followed by a low temperature static air calcination step. In the field of CO2 hydrogenation over Ru/Al2O3 catalysts, the contribution of Prof. Luca Lietti, active in the Laboratory of Catalysis and Chemical Plants at the Polytechnic of Milan, is undoubtelly relevant and has covered, during the years, the determination of kinetics [16], the effect of CO in CO2 hydrogenation [40], the development of eggshell catalysts and the evaluation of mass transport limitations [15], and the possible exploitation of Ru-based catalysts in the frame of dual functional materials [41–44]. This allowed him to contribute to a deep understanding of this catalytic system and to propose a system that can produce SNG ready for injection into the natural gas grid [45]. However, looking at possible optimization and accounting for the fact that catalyst activity and selectivity rely on the size, accessibility, and distribution of the active metal (oxide) particles over the support, it is crucial to find optimal synthesis and pretreatment [46,47]. Among the available preparation routes, incipient wetness impregnation is one of the most widely used techniques for preparing alumina-supported heterogeneous catalysts. This approach is very attractive due to its technical simplicity, scalability, cost-effectiveness, and minimal waste generation [47]. Recently, various methods have been explored in the literature to enhance Ni dispersion, including adjusting preparation conditions, enhancing interactions between the metal and support, and incorporating promoters [48–59]. Additionally, the type and properties of the solvent used may be of particular significance. Water is the conventional and most used solvent in the incipient wetness impregnation preparation method. However, the investigation of using alternative solvents has recently gained interest. Different solvents, such as cyclohexane, ethanol, ethylene glycol, glycerol and alkanols, have been investigated, and it was found that they can lead to the formation of smaller and more uniformly distributed active metal particles [49,56,60,61]. Less polar solvents were observed to increase the interaction between active phase complexes and the support surface, resulting in more stable metal species with stronger metal-support interactions. In addition, it has been reported that the use of organic solvents increased the number of weak and medium basic sites when replacing water. This supports the idea that the solvent choice can represent a critical factor in tailoring catalyst properties and performances [49,56,59,60,62–73]. Furthermore, after the wetness impregnation step, thermal treatment processes (drying, calcination, and/or reduction) are essential to obtain the catalyst in its active form. The drying step has the role of removing the solvent and ensuring the most uniform distribution of the precursor on the support [74]. Subsequent calcination and/or reduction steps facilitate the conversion of precursors into stable forms, promoting interactions between the metal species and the support and producing metal particles, which are at the basis of catalytic performance [75,76]. However, to optimize the thermal treatment conditions, it is crucial to consider the type of catalyst (including the active metal and support) and their physicochemical properties, as well as the specific goals of the intended reaction. Indeed, the sensitivity of the thermal treatment process is particularly crucial when dealing with ruthenium-based catalysts. Ruthenium can be volatile through the formation of ruthenium tetroxide (RuO4) during calcination at elevated temperatures [77,78]. RuO4 is highly toxic and poses health hazards [79], and its formation can lead to the loss of active ruthenium species from the catalyst surface, affecting catalytic performance. Several studies have shown severe sintering of ruthenium particles supported on alumina [80], silica [80,81], and zeolite A [82] when subjected to oxidative treatment prior to reduction. The oxidation treatment leads to a decrease in the support-metal oxide interaction and could result in rapid sintering upon the reduction treatment. As discussed, despite the significant improvements observed in the literature by modifying the impregnation solvent, this is not fully and systematically addressed in the open literature for Ru/Al2O3 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts in the context of CO2 methanation reaction. Considering the previously summarized studies, this work employs water (as a polar and reference solvent) and ethanol (as an organic primary alcohol solvent) for the preparation of alumina-supported Ru and Ni catalysts aiming at understanding the potential effects. Moreover, in the case of Ru, this contribution aims at ruling out the effect of calcination-reduction or direct reduction protocols onto performance under CO2 methanation conditions and at comparing the obtained results with those available in literature. On the best-performing Ru-catalyst, a systematic surface study has been carried out to shed light on the eventual displayed effects. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The investigated catalysts were prepared using Pural SB (as boehmite) as an alumina precursor produced by Sasol. Pural SB was calcined with 3 K/min at 1023 K for five hours to obtain a γ-Al2O3 as starting support. To prepare Ni/Al2O3 catalysts using the incipient wetness impregnation method, Ni(NO3)2*6H2O (Alfa Aesar) was utilized as the precursor, and it was dissolved in ethanol to compare this preparation with the well-known recipes established in the literature [14,32]. Hereafter, abbreviations will be used for Ethanol (E), Water (W), and γ-Al2O3 (A). The volume of ethanol was estimated in a way that the total volume of the solution was equal to the determined γ-Al2O3 pore volume. Ni loading was set at 13.6 wt% (13.6Ni/A_E) and 2 wt% (2Ni/A_E), to compare with water-prepared catalysts (13.6Ni/A_W) [37] and Gnp-supported materials [83]. After impregnation, the catalysts underwent a drying step at 333 K for 1 h, followed by calcination in air at 1023 K for 5 h, both with a heating rate of 2 K/min. This heat treatment procedure was identical for both the ethanol- and water-based prepared catalysts. Before each catalytic experiment, the Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were subjected to in situ reduction using a 20 % H2 - 80 % N2 mixture (% mol/mol), with a total flow rate of 80 NmL/min. The temperature was increased at a rate of 25 K/min up to 1023 K, then held for 30 min. The cooling down was performed by keeping the same atmosphere down to room temperature. Besides, to prepare Ru/Al2O3 catalysts using the incipient wetness impregnation method, Ru(NO)(NO3)3 solution, Ru 1.5 % w/v (Alfa Aesar) was used as Ru-precursor and was diluted in either ethanol or water, achieving on the final catalyst the desired Ru loading, i.e. 0.5 wt%. After the impregnation step, three different thermal treatments were considered: 1- direct reduction; using the same conditions employed for the reduction of the Ni-based catalyst, but lowering both the maximum temperature (773 K) and applied heating rate (10 K/min). These catalysts were denoted as 0.5 Ru/A_X_R1, where X represents either ethanol (E) or water (W), as mentioned before. R1 stands for the direct reduction condition. 2- heat treatment + reduction; in this case, the catalysts were thermally treated in a pure N2 flow (80 NmL/min) at 773 K for 30 min, with a heating rate of 10 K/min. Subsequently, at 773 K, the flow was switched to the reducing condition, consisting of a 20 % H2 - 80 % N2 mixture, holding the temperature for 30 min, before cooling. These catalysts were denoted as 0.5 Ru/A_X_R2. R2 stands for heat treatment followed by reduction condition. 3- air calcination + reduction; in this case, the catalysts were dried at 393 K for 2 h, followed by calcination in air at 773 K for 1 h, using a heating rate of 2 K/min. Subsequently, an in-situ R1 reduction step was performed. This series was denoted as 0.5 Ru/A_X_Cal-R1. Cal-R1 refers to catalyst calcination in air followed by reduction treatment. 2.2 Catalytic experiments Following our previous works [27,37], in steady-state catalytic experiments, a fixed-bed reactor with 88.0 mg of catalyst mixed with 700 mg of silica glass beads (0.25–0.21 mm, equivalent to 60–70 mesh sieved) was prepared. Before the catalytic experiments, the catalysts were treated in situ according to the above-described procedures. CO2 hydrogenation experiments were conducted using a gaseous flow rate of 80 NmL/min, with a H2/CO2 ratio of 5 in nitrogen dilution, used as carrier gas. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV), evaluated on catalyst volume, was equal to 55,000 h−1. To investigate any hysteresis, activation, or short-term deactivation effects, the experiments were performed both in ascending and descending reaction temperature sequences (523 K, 573 K, 623 K, 673 K, 723 K, 773 K, and in reverse). The entire catalytic experiment has a duration of over 7 h on stream. The reaction products were analyzed by FT-IR to evaluate the catalytic performance. For FT-IR online product analysis, a Nicolet 6700 FT-IR instrument was utilized. Frequencies corresponding to weak absorption of CO2, CH4, and CO molecules were employed (2293 cm−1 for CO2, 2170 cm−1 for CO, 1333 cm−1 for CH4, after baseline subtraction). The instrument was calibrated using gas mixtures with known concentrations to ensure accurate and quantitative results during the analysis process. Produced water was mostly condensed upstream of the IR cell, and from the inlet and outlet concentrations calculated using the absorbances of CO, CO2, and CH4, along with the measured total flows (to consider the variation in moles during the reaction), CO2 conversion (XCO2), selectivity, and yields to products (Si and Yi) were determined [84]. They are defined as: (6) X CO 2 = F CO 2 in − F CO 2 out F CO 2 in (7) Y i = F i F CO 2 in (8) S i = F i F CO 2 in − F CO 2 out A comparison of the obtained data using IR (averaged when deactivation is observed) was carried out using an offline gas chromatograph (GC) Agilent 4890 equipped with a Varian capillary column “Molsieve 5A/Porabond Q Tandem” and TCD and FID detectors in series and with a Ni-based methanator. The results presented in this work will be the average of the two methods, with error bars also included for the sake of completeness. Preliminary kinetics investigations were carried out on best-performing materials. The reaction order for CO2 was investigated by varying PCO2 from 0.03 to 0.07 atm at a fixed partial pressure of hydrogen PH2 = 0.30 atm. Similarly, the reaction order of H2 was studied by monitoring PH2 variations between 0.03 and 0.28 atm at a constant value of PCO2 = 0.07 atm. All experiments were performed at 573 K, assuming a differential reactor to analyze changes in the reaction order obtained. Operando experiments were carried out in a “Sandwich” home-made IR reactor cell, which consists of a stainless-steel cylinder carrying a toroidal sample holder in its center, where the self-supported wafer of catalyst is placed. The heating system guarantees to reach the required maximum temperature of 773 K on the sample upon reduction, guaranteeing proper reduction conditions. The dead volume (the residual space between each sample face and windows) is kept as low as 0.12 cm3, and the optical path is below 3 mm, allowing the acquisition of data in relevant catalytic conditions [85]. The experiments were carried out at atmospheric pressure. Gases were introduced into the lines (heated at 333 K) by mass flow controllers and forced on the sample by a 1/16 pipe and collected on the opposite side of the sample holder. The analysis of the reactants and/or the reaction products was performed by a Quadrupole Mass Spectrometry (Pfeiffer Vacuum Omnistar GSD 301) and by FTIR spectroscopy (via a gas microcell of 0.088 cm3 volume). IR spectra were collected with a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer, equipped with MCT detectors, at the maximum speed of a spectrum every 50 ms. More details about the IR operando setup can be found elsewhere [86]. Samples were pressed as self-supported wafers of around 20 mg and activated, in operando conditions, increasing the temperature up to 773 K for 30 min under a flow of 20 mL/min of Ar. After this, H2 has been introduced at 20 % (vol/vol) for 30 min, and then the system has been cooled down to reach 523 K, the chosen reaction temperature. The experiment carried out consists of three different steps, by keeping a GHSV of 55000 h−1, and coming back from one step and the other to STEP 1: • STEP 1: COx methanation: 3.33 % CO (vol/vol*100) and 3.33 % CO2 (vol/vol*100), 30 % (vol/vol*1100) H2, Ar balance; • STEP 2: Stop CO flow - CO2 methanation with the following conditions 6 % CO2 (vol/vol*100), 30 % (vol/vol*100) H2, Ar balance to acquire time resolved evolution of both gas and surface; • STEP 3: Stop CO2 flow - CO hydrogenation with the following conditions: 8.6 % CO (vol/vol*100), 30 % (vol/vol*100) H2, Ar balance to acquire time resolved evolution of both gas and surface. 2.3 Material characterizations In the case of Ru-containing materials, the in-situ reduction coupled with FT-IR was employed to characterize and assess the reducibility of the investigated materials by collecting and analyzing the reactor outlet stream upon treatment. As detailed in the preparation section and summarized in Table 1, the pretreatments were carried out under two designated conditions: R1 and R2. H2O was mostly completely condensed before the IR cell. To follow the species’ evolution, the following wavenumbers have been chosen: 1587 cm−1, 2239 cm−1, and 1890 cm−1 for NO2, N2O, and NO, respectively. X-ray diffraction profiles of both initial and spent catalysts were obtained using a vertical powder diffractometer, X′Pert. The diffractograms were continuously recorded across the 10–100° 2θ range, with increments of 0.013° and a counting duration of at least 748 s, but also reaching times of up to 1800 s. The powder patterns were indexed by comparing the 2θ values of observed peaks to those reported in Pearson's Crystal Data database [87]. FT-IR spectra were collected with a Nexus Thermo Fisher instrument with 100 scans and a spectral resolution of 2 cm−1. KBr pressed disks were used for skeletal characterization with a 1 wt% catalyst and a disk total weight of 1.00 g. Ultraviolet-visible-near infrared diffuse reflectance spectra were obtained by using a Jasco V570 instrument. Morphological and compositional analyses were carried out using an SEM ZEISS SUPRA 40 VP microscope, equipped with a field emission gun (FE-SEM). This apparatus is equipped with an "InLens" secondary electron detector, a solid-state detector for backscattered electrons (BSE), and an EDXS (Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectrometer) OXFORD "INCA Energie 450 × 3" for chemical analysis. Fresh and exhaust (after catalytic experiments) sample powders were directly affixed onto a high-purity, conductive, double-sided adhesive carbon tab. The specimens were subjected to imaging after undergoing a carbon coating procedure. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Ni-based catalysts 3.1.1 Characterization of fresh catalysts Ni-based catalysts prepared using ethanol as a solvent have been characterized through XRD, FE-SEM, FT-IR, and UV–vis–NIR. Above this temperature, over both catalysts, the forecasted thermodynamic equilibrium is approached. The reduction processes were monitored using an online FT-IR spectrometer. It is interesting to note that, independently of the applied reduction conditions, ammonia (NH3) was always found in the gas products upon the catalyst reduction process. This could open two different possibilities: the first one is the occurrence of the Haber-Bosch reaction in the H2/N2 reducing gas, (9) N2(g) + 3H2(g) ⇌ 2NH3(g) ΔH° 298 = -92.2 kJ/mol The ammonia synthesis reaction is industrially realized, primarily employing iron catalysts under high temperature and pressure [96,97]. However, ruthenium-based catalysts are well known to be even more active than Fe-based ones. Industrially, Ru-catalysts, supported on graphitic carbon have been developed by Kellogg, are manufactured today by Clariant, and are used in the Kellog Advanced Ammonia Process [98]. γ-Al2O3 has been reported to be a less suitable support for Ru catalysts in ammonia synthesis due to its high electronegativity [99], thus preferring alkali oxides, even though the adoption of suitable alumina support treatments could facilitate the development of Ru-based catalysts [100]. In any case, our data essentially confirm that all Ru/Al2O3 tested catalysts exhibit low-temperature and pressure ammonia synthesis activity. A second possibility is represented by the reduction of nitrate ions residual from the catalyst precursor to ammonia, as recently reported to occur on Ru supported over metal oxides [101] in the liquid phase. Fig. 4 displays the FT-IR absorbance profile of gaseous ammonia at 930 cm−1, along with the corresponding time and temperature data, during the catalyst pretreatment step for all investigated catalysts. Catalysts subjected to similar pretreatment conditions exhibited comparable qualitative ammonia profiles. Moreover, in each case, those prepared with ethanol demonstrate higher activity in NH3 production, except for 0.5 Ru/A_E_R2 (Fig. 4, c), which displayed relatively equal evolution profiles, independently of the used solvent. For Cal-R1 samples, where according to IR spectra, the precursor has been fully decomposed, ammonia is produced at the maximum temperature (773 K) and upon reactor cooling and this might be attributed to occurrence of the gas phase reaction (9), in line with the profiles reported in Fig. 5 where no NOx species are observed in the entire temperature range. A different situation is observed in the case of R1 samples, where a double contribution in terms of temperature is observed, with a former one observed in the temperature range 520–773 K and a latter one at 773 K, irrespective of solvent choice. Below 520 K, with a maximum at 470–480 K, N2O and NO appear as gas species with a slightly increased temperature (10 K) for 0.5Ru/A_W_R1, while remarkable amounts of NO2 are not observed. When N2O absorbance is reduced close to zero, NO is still arising from thermal treatment in H2 and, in particular, on the E-sample; NH3 starts to be produced, suggesting the occurrence of the following reaction on the W- sample and to a limited extent on the E- one, (10) NO + 5/2 H2 ⇌ NH3 + H2O where partially reduced Ru favors the successive hydrogenation of NO to ammonia as reported in the literature [102] for 1 %Ru/SiO2-Al2O3, and where H2 was reported to increase NO reduction to NH3 in CO/CO2/H2O containing atmospheres. The feature shown appears to be a function of the chosen solvent and is more remarkable for ethanol, in line with the delayed profile obtained for NOx. The high-temperature component has no dependence on the solvent choice and mostly follows the behavior observed for Cal-R1, even though with lower activity, 0.06 vs. 0.10 in terms of maximum achieved absorbance. In the case of R2 reduction, NOx species are characterized by the presence of NO2, N2O, and NO diluted in nitrogen, suggesting that in a pure inert atmosphere, NO gas can interact with 0.01–5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 with the formation of a complex mix of species including nitrite, nitrate and nitrosyl complex [103] where the role of the support might play a relevant role [104]. Also in this case, at the maximum temperature and upon H2 introduction, NH3 is detected in accordance with the above-discussed data for the 773 K step. This is in line with the thermodynamic equilibrium forecast in ammonia synthesis, at stoichiometric conditions and at low pressure [105,106]. 3.2.2 Catalytic activity in CO2 hydrogenation In Figs. 4S and 5S, the most relevant data obtained by GC and IR during CO2 hydrogenation experiments are separately introduced, while in Fig. 6, their averaged values are reported. For reader’s convenience a summary of catalytic results is also available in Table 2S. The above-discussed results, including slight deactivation at low temperature, could play well with the results obtained upon CO hydrogenation over Ru/Al2O3 catalysts [107], indeed more relevant for R1 and Cal-R1 samples. For this purpose, the methane molar concentration has been fitted with an exponential decay function, giving rise to the Eq. (11) [108]: (11) CCH4 = CCH4,qss + A exp(R0*t) where CCH4 is the methane concentration in mol/mL on a dry basis at time t; CCH4,qss is the methane concentration in mol/mL on a dry basis at the final point; A is a pre-exponential factor in mol/mL, and R0 is expressed in s−1. In the case of 2Ni/A_E, despite having only a 2 wt% nickel loading, the obtained result (Ea = 84 kJ/mol) aligns well with findings for Ni/Al2O3 [27,32,109,110], even though in those cases, the Ni loading ranges from 10 to 30 wt%. The corresponding spectra versus time are reported below and in ESI (Fig. 7 and Fig. 8S). Upon introduction of the mixed COx methanation flow, several bands appear and evolve with time; at time t = 0.0 min, reactants are fed and after 0.4 min carbonyl species with a complex feature centered at 1980 cm−1 (Fig. 7b) appears (Ru-carbonyls) together with bands at 3610, 1657, 1438 and 1228 cm−1 due to OH stretching, asymmetric and symmetric OCO-stretching and OH deformation vibrations of the adsorbed monohydrogencarbonate ions species, typically formed by CO2 adsorption on hydroxylated alumina [14,114], with other bands also growing in the OH stretching region. Meanwhile, MS recorded a reduction of fragment at m/z = 2, probably due to the parallel occurring H2 dissociative adsorption reaction [16]; monohydrogencarbonate bands steadily increase their intensity over time. In parallel, after 0.49 min, perturbation of the OH stretching band at 3768 cm−1 (due to surface hydroxy-groups of alumina) is observed (it appears as a negative band in the subtracted spectrum), with the growth of the OH band at 3601 cm−1. (Fig. 7d). A close look at the spectra pointed out the presence of a shoulder at 1470 cm−1, suggesting the formation of another family of hydrogencarbonates, whose associated vibrations overlap with the aforementioned bands of the main feature. However, the band at 1470 cm−1 could be the evidence of the formation of methoxy species (CH3 asymmetric deformation), which was reported to act as an intermediate in the methanation of formates produced from CO hydrogenation over Ni/Al2O3. It has been shown that surface methoxides, even produced from methanol, are easily converted to methane over transition metal supported catalysts [115]. According to the proposed model of alumina of Busca et al., this converges with the idea that monohydrogencarbonates are formed by reaction of CO2 with the alumina hydroxy groups absorbing at 3768 cm−1, i.e., terminal OH’ over tetrahedral-like Al ions and near a vacancy (Fig. 7d, IA sites) [88,116], with a possible contribution of IB. Interestingly, in the 3750–3500 cm−1 region, there is an increase of band intensities (ν(OH) of type IIA, type III and H-bonded species) with a broad decaying behavior at lower wavenumbers; this can be attributed to hydroxylation of alumina surface that plays well with the delay in the m/z = 18 observation, that occurs when the maximum intensity is achieved on the surface. This indicates that water is formed, implying that COx reduction by hydrogen is occurring. At the same time of monohydrogencarbonates, a complex carbonyl band growths with at least two features at 2028 cm−1 and 1980 cm−1, and then giving rise to three bands at 2059, 2024, and 1972 cm−1, with relative intensities changing upon time evolution; a deconvolution of the spectra suggests the possibility to identify up to six bands, with a quite complex behavior that is still matter of debate in the literature. Shading light on this point, spectroscopic data for CO adsorption on Ru(0001) plane monocrystal face [117,118] show that CO adsorbs on top with a CO stretching of near 1980 cm−1 at the lowest coverages, shifting up to 2060–2080 cm−1 at the higher ones, due to coupling effects. A similar situation occurs on the stepped Ru(109) face, where CO linearly adsorbs and its CO stretching vibration shifts from 1973 cm−1 at the lowest coverages to 2063 cm−1 at saturation coverage [119]. We may also remark that the IR spectrum of Ru3(CO)12, triruthenium dodecacarbonyl, where all carbonyl species are terminal, shows bands at 2066, 2032, 2005, and 1985 cm⁻¹ due to couplings of the three Ru(CO)4 groups [120]. Bands in the region 2140–1980 cm−1 were also attributed to cationic monoruthenium polycarbonyl species such as [Ru(CO)4]2- and [Ru(CO)3]2- [121]. [Ru(CO)2]3+ [122] and [Ru(CO)2]2+ [123] and are formed by decomposition of Ru3(CO)12 on γ-Al2O3, supposed to produce monoruthenium polycarbonyl species [120]. As reviewed years ago by Hadjiivanov et al. [123], CO adsorbs exclusively linearly over ruthenium species supported on oxides. In fact, bridging CO on ruthenium centers, absorbing < 1950 cm−1, seems to be quite unusual in both neutral and cationic complexes [124], where most bands are observed > 2050 cm−1, although they may exist in complexes [124]. Similarly, CO adsorbed on relatively high-loading Ru/Al2O3 catalysts shows a main C-O stretching shifting from approx. 1990 cm−1 to 2037 cm−1 at increasing coverage, which might be attributed to the on-top CO interaction with large metal particles [14]. However, for low loading Ru/Al2O3 or after breaking of ruthenium particles [125], CO stretching bands at higher frequency are commonly found, suggesting that cationic Ru (poly)carbonyls may be formed. Thus, considering the low loading of our sample and the apparent good dispersion of ruthenium species, as well as the absence of significant shift of CO bands with coverage, we can tentatively attribute the bands we observe at 2024 and 2059 cm−1 and above to terminal CO, as mono- or poly-carbonyl species, on isolated ruthenium particles or very small clusters, and the component at 1972–1980 cm−1 to weaklier held CO on larger clusters. Only at the final time of the experiment, a weak emerging shoulder at 1839 cm−1 can be glimpsed, suggesting a partial surface reconstruction, maybe producing a bridging CO species. A broad band centered at 1763 cm−1, appearing during the first stages of CO and CO2 introduction, could be tentatively assigned to the so-called “organic-like” carbonates that have been really identified as strongly perturbed CO2 molecules [126]. Above 0.9 min, three sharp new bands appear at 1377, 1393, and 1593 cm−1 associated with the symmetric OCO-stretching, CH-deformation, and asymmetric OCO-stretching of formates, whose intensity increases with time on stream, with the corresponding band at 2930 cm−1 assigned to the C-H stretching vibration (Fig. 7a) and c)). Interestingly, methane started to be formed when carbonyls and both monohydrogencarbonate families started to be present at the surface and following the mechanism passing through monohydrogencarbonates-formates proposed in the literature [40,128]. In addition, the above presented data support the idea of strongly bonded adsorbed CO that competes with H2 adsorption producing catalyst passivation more than deactivation, because, in the present case, no carboxylate nor CxHy species in relevant amounts were observed, but the appearance of bands at 2154 and 2159 cm−1 might support either the unlikely occurrence of a slight ruthenium oxidation or the evidence of a small release of Ru carbonyls in the gas phase [124]; in any case, this cannot exclude a limited carbon deposit on the catalysts upon the present experiment. In the Ni/Al2O3 case, according to literature available operando results [129] the observed species are apparently the same we detected in Ru-case, even though formates appear already at the beginning of the experiment, where monohydrogencarbonates are not observed, followed then by carbonate species. This suggests a possible modification of the reported mechanism that however has been not explicitly verified on the materials investigated in this study. It can be noticed that, as expected, gaseous phase CO decreases, showing the negative behavior centered in correspondence with the CO gas fingerprint at 2143 cm−1, replaced by CO2. Interestingly, first a slight increase of monohydrogencarbonate features is observed, followed by their consumption, bringing the characteristic bands (1648, 1440, 1229 cm−1) negative (Fig. 8b). This suggests that we achieved their maximum concentration at the surface with limited changes in the timeframe of the experiment; in parallel, the group I formates showed an increase of their characteristic bands over time with features centered at 1393, 1373, and 1594 cm−1, suggesting the occurrence of the hydrogenation of monohydrogencarbonate species, as it is also confirmed by the presence of isosbestic points in Fig. 8b and by the global profile of band intensities (Fig. 8c). However, quite relevant differences are observed in the carbonyl region with the disappearance of features at 2066 and 2036 cm−1 that well match with an increase in methane production on MS, and a growth in intensity of the band at 1960 cm−1 with a possible broad shoulder at 2000 cm−1 (Fig. 8d), that support the idea of ruthenium carbonyls produced at low CO coverage. As a consequence, these sites can be considered as the active centers for this transformation. It is worth pointing out that, during the experiment, the methane profile (m/z = 15) reached the steady-state conditions with an increased intensity, in agreement with literature [40]. For the sake of comparison, the fresh calcined samples are also reported in Fig. 10S, supporting the quite remarkable inhomogeneity in terms of Ru distribution. As evident from the images in Fig. 12, both catalysts that underwent Cal-R1 treatment, regardless of whether they were prepared with ethanol or water, exhibited a wide range of Ru nanoparticles, falling in two distinct two ranges: a former in 10–50 nm and a latter one ∼200 nm or more, in line with the dispersion observed in the freshly calcined materials. These findings align with the existing literature, which underscores that the oxidation treatment of supported ruthenium catalysts disrupts the interactions between the support and the active phase, resulting in a rapid sintering [15,80–82] . Moreover, it is known that Ru particle size can significantly affect catalytic activity. Ru nanoparticles have shown a structure sensitive behavior in CO Fischer Tropsch when particle sizes are lower than 10 nm on Ru/Al2O3 catalysts [120] and in CO methanation [130] on Ru/C catalysts (4–8 nm size), while this effect has been not clearly pointed out in the case of ammonia synthesis [131]. Thus, according to the cited literature, the catalytic activity of Ru is often structure-sensitive in hydrogenation but this is not clearly and extensively addressed for CO2 hydrogenation, thus hindering also an additional deep discussion. In fact, there is no universal optimal size and possibly shape; as an example, in CO2 methanation over Ru/TiO2 catalysts, peak activity has been reported at particle sizes of ∼3 nm [132], suggesting that previous discussion on hydrogenation might be extended also to Sabatier’s reaction and agrees with our findings, where the best ethanol-based catalyst treated under R2 conditions showed Ru particle sizes below 5 nm. It should be noted that, as already reported in our previous works [14,32], no coke formation was observed in our experiments conducted over a 6-hour timescale, as evidenced by FE-SEM and XRD studies. 4 Conclusion In this work, the catalytic performance of Ni/Al2O3 and Ru/Al2O3 catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation was studied, with an emphasis on the crucial roles of solvent selection and pretreatment conditions, as a part of systematic studies of these systems. 13.6 wt% Ni/Al2O3 prepared with ethanol as solvent demonstrated superior methane production during the ascending phase, while the water-prepared one performed slightly better during the descending phase, thus suggesting a limited impact of the solvent on catalysts performances. A reduction of the Ni loading down to 2 wt% resulted in a decreased methane yield and increased selectivity to CO, produced through rWGS reaction. In the case of Ru/Al2O3 catalysts, the choice of solvent and pretreatment conditions significantly influenced the catalytic activity and selectivity. Ethanol-prepared catalysts exhibited higher activity, particularly 0.5Ru/A_E_R2, which showed the highest level of activity. The pretreatment condition of R2 proved to be the most effective, ensuring an acceptable catalyst stability also in the descending phase. Characterizations of Ru-based catalysts, including in-situ reduction, revealed insights into ammonia and NOx productions that are affected by solvent selection and pretreatment conditions. In the morphological characterizations, differences in Ru nanoparticle sizes were observed based on solvent and pretreatment, with appreciable sintering effects in catalysts already upon calcination. The assessment of kinetic parameters of CO2 hydrogenation, focusing on apparent activation energy (Ea), revealed a consistent behavior among Ru-based catalysts that underwent the same heat treatment and reduction conditions, regardless of the solvent used. Operando studies in COx/CO/CO2 streams supported the monohydrogencarbonate–formate–carbonyl route for COx hydrogenation at the temperature of 523 K, evidencing the existence of two monohydrogencarbonate and formates species produced on the alumina surface, on specific sites; as well, a different distribution of the carbonyl species is detected and contribute to the activity and selectivity of the best performing material obtained in present conditions. coredata.dc:description: Ru/Al2O3 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared and investigated in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. 0.5 wt% Ru/Al2O3, 2 wt% Ni/Al2O3, and 13.6 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by using a modified incipient wetness impregnation with a main focus on the effect of solvent selection and catalyst pretreatment conditions on the catalyst reduction, activity, selectivity, activation energy, and morphology. In-depth characterizations, including FT-IR, FE-SEM, and XRD, were performed on the catalysts, and an operando study was carried out on the best-performing Ru-catalysts in COx transient experiments at 523 K. The investigation revealed that employing ethanol as the solvent for preparation results in a catalyst with improved properties and activity. Furthermore, coupling solvent selection with various pretreatment conditions demonstrated that specific pretreatments can significantly affect the catalyst properties, activity, and morphology. Operando IR confirmed the mechanism and the effect of CO reported in the literature, even if a different distribution of carbonyl species was detected.
